3: The superstition upon this tale is very general in the East. Among the Arabs, it appears to be common: it did not extend itself to the Greeks until after the establishment of Christianity; and it has only assumed its form since the division of the Latin and Greek churches. At that time, the idea becoming prevalent, that a Latin body could not be buried in their territory, it gradually increased, and formed the subject of many wonderful stories, still extant, of the dead rising from their graves, and feeding upon the blood of the young and beautiful. In the West it spread, with some slight variation, all over Hungary, Poland, Austria, and Lorraine, where the heroes existed, that vompyresnightly imbi6ed a certain portion of the blood of their victims, who became emaciated, lost their strength, and speedily died of consumption; whilst these human blood-suckers fattened—and their veins became distended to such a state of completion, as to cause the blood to flow from all the passages of their bodies, and even from the orifices of their skins.
